trans-unit.source: Consider setting the replay detection feature (DetectReplayedTokens) to true
trans-unit.target: Consider setting the replay detection feature (DetectReplayedTokens) to true

trans-unit.source: WIF has a replay detection cache specifically for security token service (STS) bearer tokens, which is just a cache of previously used STS tokens.
trans-unit.target: WIF has a replay detection cache specifically for security token service (STS) bearer tokens, which is just a cache of previously used STS tokens.

trans-unit.source: When the client first authenticates to the relying party using the STS token, it receives a session security token that it uses to authenticate to the relying party for any additional requests.
trans-unit.target: When the client first authenticates to the relying party using the STS token, it receives a session security token that it uses to authenticate to the relying party for any additional requests.

trans-unit.source: It does this over Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) so that the session security token cannot be stolen.
trans-unit.target: It does this over Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) so that the session security token cannot be stolen.

trans-unit.source: If a client or an attacker tries to authenticate to the relying party with an STS token that the client has used already, the relying party can look up the STS token in the replay cache and refuse the request.
trans-unit.target: If a client or an attacker tries to authenticate to the relying party with an STS token that the client has used already, the relying party can look up the STS token in the replay cache and refuse the request.

trans-unit.source: This cache does not guarantee that a token can never be replayed.
trans-unit.target: This cache does not guarantee that a token can never be replayed.

trans-unit.source: It performs best-effort detection based on the size of the cache, the expiration time of the STS token, and the rate of unique authentication requests received by the relying party.
trans-unit.target: It performs best-effort detection based on the size of the cache, the expiration time of the STS token, and the rate of unique authentication requests received by the relying party.

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend that you set the cache size and STS token expiration time for your relying party to get the right balance between performance and security.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend that you set the cache size and STS token expiration time for your relying party to get the right balance between performance and security.

trans-unit.source: Set the requireHttps attribute of wsFederation to true
trans-unit.target: Set the requireHttps attribute of wsFederation to true

trans-unit.source: The <ui>requireHttps</ui> attribute controls whether the module will only redirect a secure URL for the STS.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>requireHttps</ui> attribute controls whether the module will only redirect a secure URL for the STS.

trans-unit.source: The default is “true”.
trans-unit.target: The default is “true”.

trans-unit.source: This ensures secure communications with STS over clear HTTPS/SSL traffic, mitigating credentials and token sniffing over the wire.
trans-unit.target: This ensures secure communications with STS over clear HTTPS/SSL traffic, mitigating credentials and token sniffing over the wire.

trans-unit.source: List trusted STS (token issuers) in issuerNameRegistry
trans-unit.target: List trusted STS (token issuers) in issuerNameRegistry

trans-unit.source: All issuer tokens are validated using the IssuerNameRegistry.
trans-unit.target: All issuer tokens are validated using the IssuerNameRegistry.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of the IssuerNameRegistry is to map the issuer token to a string name.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of the IssuerNameRegistry is to map the issuer token to a string name.

trans-unit.source: If validation fails the token will not be accepted.
trans-unit.target: If validation fails the token will not be accepted.

trans-unit.source: This mitigates the threat of accepting tokens that are not trusted.
trans-unit.target: This mitigates the threat of accepting tokens that are not trusted.

trans-unit.source: Any custom type can be registered using the <embeddedLabel>type</embeddedLabel> attribute of the <issuerNameRegistry> element.
trans-unit.target: Any custom type can be registered using the <embeddedLabel>type</embeddedLabel> attribute of the <issuerNameRegistry> element.

trans-unit.source: The <issuerNameRegistry> can have one child element that will serve as custom configuration to the IssuerNameRegistry.
trans-unit.target: The <issuerNameRegistry> can have one child element that will serve as custom configuration to the IssuerNameRegistry.

trans-unit.source: One IssuerNameRegistry type is provided out of the box—ConfigurationBasedIssuerNameRegistry—that can be used to configure a set of trusted issuer certificates in configuration.
trans-unit.target: One IssuerNameRegistry type is provided out of the box—ConfigurationBasedIssuerNameRegistry—that can be used to configure a set of trusted issuer certificates in configuration.

trans-unit.source: This type requires a child configuration element <trustedIssuers> where trusted issuer certificates configured.
trans-unit.target: This type requires a child configuration element <trustedIssuers> where trusted issuer certificates configured.

trans-unit.source: <trustedIssuers> configuration adds trusted certificatess using the ASN.1 encoded form of the certificate thumbprint.
trans-unit.target: <trustedIssuers> configuration adds trusted certificatess using the ASN.1 encoded form of the certificate thumbprint.

trans-unit.source: It is specified when you are creating or configuring the relying party using the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal or Management Service.
trans-unit.target: It is specified when you are creating or configuring the relying party using the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal or Management Service.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Token Lifetime property to specify the amount of time for a security token issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to the relying party application to remain valid.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Token Lifetime property to specify the amount of time for a security token issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> to the relying party application to remain valid.

trans-unit.source: By default, in <token>secondref_acs</token>, this value is set to 10 minutes (600 seconds).
trans-unit.target: By default, in <token>secondref_acs</token>, this value is set to 10 minutes (600 seconds).

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, this value must be greater than zero but less than or equal to 24 hours (86400 seconds).
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, this value must be greater than zero but less than or equal to 24 hours (86400 seconds).

trans-unit.source: Provide adequate data validation when using the Error URL feature
trans-unit.target: Provide adequate data validation when using the Error URL feature

trans-unit.source: You can use the Error URL to specify a URL to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Error URL to specify a URL to which <token>secondref_acs</token> redirects users if an error occurs during the login process.

trans-unit.source: It can be a custom page hosted on the relying party application, for example, http://www.fabrikam.com/billing/error.aspx.
trans-unit.target: It can be a custom page hosted on the relying party application, for example, http://www.fabrikam.com/billing/error.aspx.

trans-unit.source: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> supplies details about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.
trans-unit.target: As part of the redirect, <token>secondref_acs</token> supplies details about the error to the relying party application as a JSON-encoded HTTP URL parameter.

trans-unit.source: The custom error page can be crafted to consume the JSON-encoded error information to render the actual error message received or display static help text.
trans-unit.target: The custom error page can be crafted to consume the JSON-encoded error information to render the actual error message received or display static help text.

trans-unit.source: If the page requires authorization, the result will be an infinite-redirection loop in a case where <token>secondref_acs</token> will try to access it and send the JSON encoded error.
trans-unit.target: If the page requires authorization, the result will be an infinite-redirection loop in a case where <token>secondref_acs</token> will try to access it and send the JSON encoded error.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, it should be configured for anonymous access.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, it should be configured for anonymous access.

trans-unit.source: Because the page can be accessed anonymously and because it might include code that echoes back HTML or write data to the database, you should take steps to prevent cross-site scripting and SQL Injection attacks.
trans-unit.target: Because the page can be accessed anonymously and because it might include code that echoes back HTML or write data to the database, you should take steps to prevent cross-site scripting and SQL Injection attacks.

trans-unit.source: In Azure, the default cookie encryption mechanism (which uses data protection application programming interfaces (DPAPI)) is not appropriate because each instance has a different key.
trans-unit.target: In Azure, the default cookie encryption mechanism (which uses data protection application programming interfaces (DPAPI)) is not appropriate because each instance has a different key.

trans-unit.source: This would mean that a cookie created by one web role instance would not be readable by another web role instance.
trans-unit.target: This would mean that a cookie created by one web role instance would not be readable by another web role instance.

trans-unit.source: This could lead to service failures, effectively causing denial of the service.
trans-unit.target: This could lead to service failures, effectively causing denial of the service.
